results.abstract: Before the release of the sequel “Avatar: The Way of Water,” the iconoclastic filmmaker explains why he’s bringing the first film back to theaters.

results.title: The Multiplying Horror of Ti West
results.abstract: With “X” and “Pearl,” the writer and director has released two related horror movies in the last six months, with a third on the way. The filmmaker discusses his quick building of a little horror universe.

results.title: ‘The 400 Blows,’ a Directing Debut That Still Astonishes
results.abstract: In 1959, François Truffaut premiered his first film, about a Parisian boy playing hooky, and moviemaking hasn’t been the same since.

multimedia.caption: Jean-Pierre Léaud as the director François Truffaut’s alter ego in “The 400 Blows.”

results.title: Sarah Michelle Gellar Returns to High School Drama — as the Headmaster
results.abstract: After a break from the spotlight, the actress is poised for a comeback, starting with a role in the Netflix film “Do Revenge.”

results.abstract: The actors perform their own stunts, including a couple of flips to the dirt, in this scene from the film. The director Gina Prince-Bythewood narrates.

results.title: Jack Charles, Grandfather of Aboriginal Theater, Dies at 79
results.abstract: One of Australia’s leading Indigenous actors, he had a resonant voice, a charismatic personality and a troubled personal life that often landed him in jail.

multimedia.caption: Jack Charles, known to fans as Uncle Jack, had a voice that made people stop and listen.

results.title: Alain Tanner, Leading Director in Swiss New Wave, Dies at 92
results.abstract: With his brainy works of neorealism, he made films that helped establish Switzerland as a film center in the 1970s.
des_facet: Jonah Who Will Be 25 in the Year 2000 (Movie)

multimedia.caption: Alain Tanner in 1985. He was a founder of the so-called Group of 5, norm-shattering Swiss directors who helped drive a new form of cinema starting in the late 1960s.

results.title: Bad Bunny, No. 1 Again, Puts a Spotlight on Inequities in Puerto Rico
results.abstract: Days before his latest album notched its 11th week atop the Billboard 200, the pop superstar released a music video paired with a documentary by Bianca Graulau.

multimedia.caption: Bad Bunny onstage in Philadelphia this month. Last week he released a video for his song “El Apagón” that included an 18-minute documentary examining inequities in Puerto Rican real estate.

results.title: Apple Shot an Oscar Contender Starring Will Smith. That Was Before the Slap.
results.abstract: The Civil War drama “Emancipation” finished filming early this year. Now, Apple faces a quandary on what to do with the movie.

results.title: Henry Silva, Actor Who Specialized in Menace, Dies at 95
results.abstract: He was forever cast as a thug, a hit man or some other nefarious character. But he took pride in his ability to play each bad guy differently.

multimedia.caption: Henry Silva, right, with Sammy Davis Jr. and Elizabeth Montgomery in a scene from the 1963 film “Johnny Cool,” in which Mr. Silva played the title character, an assassin for a mob boss.

results.title: ‘God’s Country’ Review: A Solitary Woman Isn’t Left Alone for Long
results.abstract: In this simmering thriller, Thandiwe Newton plays a professor in rural Montana who confronts two hunters who say they’re just passing through.

results.title: ‘The Woman King’ Review: She Slays
results.abstract: Viola Davis leads a strong cast into battle in an epic from Gina Prince-Bythewood, inspired by real women warriors.

multimedia.caption: In “The Woman King,” Viola Davis leads the women warriors of Dahomey, a real regiment in 19th-century Africa whose exact origins remain obscured by tribal myths and oral traditions.

results.title: ‘Moonage Daydream’ Review: David Bowie’s Sound and Vision
results.abstract: Brett Morgen’s new documentary about the singer uses archival material, not talking heads. But the film is more séance than biography.
